ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned a lottt about the functioning of central banks, mainly the US. There's a lot of material so you definitely go into detail on every aspect.

This course provides an in depth outline of the organization and roles of the central bank, with examples focusing on case studies of the Fed but also international central banks. Eased into the material very well, but later allows for an incredible interwoven network of themes and information that we can use to argue during case studies, tabletop exercises, and outside the course as well.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths - it goes into a lot of depth and the order which you learn things is well organized. There are assignments spread out over lots of areas - eg case studies, two papers & a rewrite, final, and tabletop exercises, which means you are able to work on your grade and not have it be defined by any one assignment. Weaknesses - no clarity on the grading at the beginning of the semester, and was harder to know where you stand since there are so many grad students. The multitude of assignments meant a high workload that wasn't necessarily to learning more. The lectures could sometimes be dry and there was not often material discussed that wasn't written on the slides. There was a sample exam provided but no answers and it was frustrating sometimes to have the group discussion exercises left up to randomization.

The course was absolutely incredible, allowing for such inn depth information and pursuing own interests through paper topics and weekly coffee chats. The professor and TAs worked together really well to make the material accessible to all (writing as an undergrad, while the overwhelming majority of students were graduate students, and even with experience working at the Fed).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No, unless you already have a strong background in central banking or are really interested in the topic.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested, be it undergrad or graduate student, as the professor explains all material incredibly well and provides engaging assignments to further student interest.
